Package tk.shardsoftware.screens

Class GameScreen

  • java.lang.Object
    • tk.shardsoftware.screens.GameScreen
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    com.badlogic.gdx.Screen
    public class GameScreen
extends java.lang.Object
implements com.badlogic.gdx.Screen
    Handles game controls, rendering, and logic
    Author:
    James Burnell, Hector Woods

      • setPlayerStartPosition

        public void setPlayerStartPosition()
        Search the world map for a region that contains only water to spawn the * player in. Once this has been found, it will set the player position to this location.

      • setPlayerCollege

        public void setPlayerCollege​(java.lang.String collegeName)
        Starts a timer that increments points, starts playing music and ambient noise.
        Parameters:
        collegeName - the name of the college the player belongs to

      • Restart

        public void Restart()
        Restarts the game, generating a new map with colleges, clearing entities e.t.c.

      • calcPlayerGoalAngle

        public static int calcPlayerGoalAngle()
        Calculates the goal angle of the player ship based on user input. If no input is provided, the angle will be -999 to easily detect when the ship should not rotate.
        Calculates NESW directions, their diagonals, and any cancelled directions due to contradictory inputs.
        Returns:
        -999 if there is no input,
        -333 if the input cancels out,
        the angle the player should rotate towards otherwise.

      • placeColleges

        public void placeColleges()
        Calls College.generateColleges(), generating the colleges on the map, and adds them to the entity handler.

      • lerpCamera

        private void lerpCamera​(com.badlogic.gdx.math.Vector2 target,
                        float speed,
                        float delta)
        Moves the camera smoothly to the target position
        Parameters:
        target - the position the camera should move to
        speed - the speed ratio the camera moves by.
        In range [0,1], where 0 is no movement and 1 is instant movement
        delta - the time elapsed since the last update in seconds
